oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Vern Gosdin and the Nitty Gritty Dirt Band Interviews - Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: First half of recording is recording of an interview with Vern Gosdin (performer) conducted by Biff Collie. Second half of the recording is of an interview with the Nitty Gritty Dirt Band (performance group) conducted by Biff Collie.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Vern Gosdin; Biff Collie; Nitty Gritty Dirt Band
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Vern Gosdin tells Biff Collie about being questioned about what had changed about him; Gosdin says he got a new car -- (00:45) Gosdin reflects on how George Jones and Merle Haggard believe him to be a 'singer-singer' -- (01:03) "That Just About Does It" is told, by Gosdin, to be a song about a breakup that Gosdin saw happening, and Collie and Gosdin joke about domestic relationships -- (01:59) Gosdin examines how "Take Me Home to Alabama" was a track presented to him at a concert, he was performing, in Florida -- (02:32) Gosdin and Collie discuss how Hank Cochran was included in the pre-production of "Take Me Home to Alabama" -- (03:47) "I'm Still Crazy" is discussed by Gosdin as a recollection of a time he arrived home to an empty home -- (05:36) Collie and Gosdin joke about Gosdin getting ahead of the program -- (05:56) "Paradise '83" is described by Gosdin as a time in Jacksonville, Florida where he worked with his recently sober friend Dane Dillon -- (07:10) Gosdin recalls his ex-wife feeling detrimental to Gosdin in "Do Me a Favor" and Gosdin tells of when he showed "Do Me a Favor" to Max T. Barnes -- (09:07) Gosdin and Collie discuss Gosdin's past success on his first CBS album -- (09:29) Collie introduces Gosdin's career path -- (10:05) Gosdin discusses always being under contract for his extensive career -- (10:55) Gosdin describes "Tanqueray" is set in Amarillo, Texas and describes how the song reflects a love affair -- (12:34) Gosdin addresses "Alone" and refers to a single line written by Barnes -- (13:06) "Right in the Wrong Direction" is told by Gosdin as another song about his ex-wife -- (13:30) Gosdin describes how he and Barnes had written "I'm Only Going Crazy" and Gosdin reflects on the theme of marrying his house-keeper -- (14:17) Gosdin jokes about his ex-wife and "You're Not by Yourself" is described by Gosdin as his feeling when his wife left him -- (15:02) Gosdin says 'So Long' (incomplete) -- (15:10) Will the Circle Be Unbroken Part 2 is introduced by Collie and Fadden And Fadden Recalls the first Will the Circle Be Unbroken as being an album focused on the group's country roots -- (17:10) Collie and Fadden discuss the recording technique of two-track recording -- (17:30) Fadden recalls "Life's Highway to Heaven" being a track that was recorded in half a day and Fadden and Collie reflect on how two-track recording affected the recording -- (19:10) Collie and Fadden reflect on Johnny Cash being a role model -- (19:14) Collie and Fadden reflect on traditional songs' ability to have variation in title and lyrics -- (19:37) Fadden cerebrates "Grandpa Was a Carpenter" is a great song about people's impact -- (20:14) Collie and Fadden discuss imagery in John Prine songs and reflect on Prine not being recognized as a country artist -- (20:36) "When I get My Rewards" writer Paul Kennerley and lead vocal Levon Helm are celebrated by Fadden as drivers of the Nitty Gritty Dirt Band's image -- (21:39) Collie and Fadden reflect on Helm's acting career and Fadden discusses how Helm goes above the norm -- (22:38) Collie reasserts Helm is one of his favorite actors and Fadden reflects on how Helm and Fadden's father had similar interests -- (23:39) Fadden and Collie discuss changing "Don't You Hear Jerusalem Moan" from the 'new grass revival' styling -- (24:12) Collie and Fadden reflect on the traditional influence on Will the Circle Be Unbroken Part 2 -- (25:07) Fadden reflects on Helm's work and addresses the value of song-writers -- (25:21) "Little Mountain Church House" is told by Fadden to be centered around a 'new traditional' style and jokes about Ricky Skaggs being a terrible singer -- (26:30) Fadden discusses the techniques needed to fade out "Little Mountain Church House" using two-track recording -- (27:14) Fadden discusses recording with Jimmy Martin and Skaggs -- (27:34) "And So It Goes" lead vocalist John Denver is reflected on by Fadden telling how the track helped Denver get his country career back on track -- (28:41) Fadden tells how each song only required one recording day -- (29:23) "When It's Gone" is told by Fadden to be a traditional song that took visiting Don Schlitz's help to create -- (30:11) Fadden discusses his favorite songs are those that make emotional statements -- (30:45) Fadden reflects on the amount of artists and self-recorded tracks they allowed on the album -- (31:07) Fadden reflects on the California record influence affect on country artists change to pop music (32:55) Fadden recalls the differential style of the Nitty Gritty Dirt Band in musical performances -- (33:18) Fadden reflects on "Mary Danced With Soldiers" being a traditional song sung by Emmylou Harris, and how the Nitty Gritty Dirt band adapts to each artist they record -- (34:24) Fadden reflects on Harris and changes in playing based on family needs -- (35:35) "Riding Alone" is told by Fadden to be originally being named "Range Pickle" and Fadden reflects on the changing perception he had for his band members -- (36:58) Fadden describes the reactions of Chet Atkins and Harris after they recorded "Riding Alone" -- (37:54) Collie and Fadden discuss Fadden recording "I'm Sitting on Top of the World" and working with Martin and Skaggs in the same day -- (38:58) Collie and Fadden reflect on living in Los Angeles, performing at McCabe's, and ditching school -- (40:35) Collie addresses the half way mark and Fadden wishes the listeners enjoy Will the Circle be Unbroken Part 2 -- (41:01) Collie recaps Fadden being on the Music City Album Review and Collie and Fadden discuss Liberty Records giving Fadden recording freedom allowing Fadden to record the album in ten days -- (42:10) Collie and Fadden discuss Scruggs' helpfulness in collaborating artists for the album -- (42:58) Fadden brings up the change in drumming for the new album; this was due to an abundance of guitar payers -- (43:38) The year "Lovin' on the Side" was written is joked about by Fadden, Fadden reflects on the 'two-step' style of the song, and Paulette Carlson is told to be a major factor -- (45:06) Collie and Fadden reflect on Carlson coming from Minnesota and the re-writes done on "Lovin' on the Side" -- (46:24) Fadden recalls playing Harmonica with a symphony in downtown Nashville -- (46:35) Fadden tells that the album is an homage to the band's friend group and the changes of time -- (47:48) Fadden tells of how "Bayou Jubilee" pianist Bruce Hornsby was asked to perform on "Bayou Jubilee" -- (49:28) Fadden asserts the historical significance of the Will the Circle Be Unbroken without the intention to be historically significant -- (51:36) Fadden describes "Blues Berry Hill" violin player Vassar Clements performance style and recalls Clements describing his playing technique -- (52:53) Fadden describes how "Blue Berry Hill" got its name and Fadden and Collie discuss the various terms used to describe various aspects of the Nitty Gritty Dirt Band -- (53:43) "One Step Over the Line" is addressed as a Rosanne Cash and John Hiatt track Fadden believes to be a 'Honky Tonk' song -- (54:42) Collie has Fadden recall the time he had met Acuff at Acuff Rose -- (55:20) Collie steers the conversation to Acuff and Fadden describes playing ping pong with Acuff to determine what kind of people made the Nitty Gritty Dirt Band -- (56:14) Fadden describes the first encounter with Acuff in the studio and Fadden and Collie describe the pressure of the situation Fadden faced -- (57:14) "Turn of the Century" is described to be a J. Fred Knobloch and Dan Tyler song that is the Nitty Gritty Dirt Band's outlook of the future -- (58:05) Fadden discusses "You Ain't Goin' Nowhere" and its relationship with the Country Rock album -- (58:39) Fadden reflects on Chris Hillman's musical career -- (59:35) Fadden shows his appreciation for Scruggs' contributions on the album; this includes the album's final track "Amazing Grace" -- (1:00:35) "The Valley Road" is described by Fadden as the Nitty Gritty Dirt Band's fastest track and recalls another record company employee listening in to the recording -- (1:01:45) Fadden describes Hornsby's styling and similarity to Helm and John Anderson -- (1:02:42) "Will the Circle Be Unbroken" is the only multi-track recording and Fadden and Collie reflect on the staggering number of artists -- (1:03:44) Fadden details Roy Acuff's performance in the recording -- (1:04:42) Collie recaps the interview for Fadden and Fadden corrects Collie about John Denver -- (1:05:13) Fadden addresses Scruggs, Clements, Husky, Douglas, Thomas, Murphey and McGuinn while recalling his enjoyment when recording the album -- (1:06:23) Collie and Fadden address the Nitty Gritty Dirt Band and the change of musical tastes in Fadden's youth dictating the Nitty Gritty Dirt Band's style -- (1:07:33) Fadden and Collie say their goodbyes
